Some ufologists have attempted to re-interpret premodern art to support pseudohistorical claims of ancient alien interactions with humanity. Ufologists claim that early portrayals of flying discs can establish a historical basis for their existence as physical craft or some other type of external phenomena. However, experts have consistently explained purported portrayals of ancient UFOs as artifacts of the cultures producing them. For example, Italian Renaissance painter Carlo Crivelli put a disc-shaped element in his 1486 altarpiece The Annunciation, with Saint Emidius that art historian Massimo Polidoro described as "a vortex of angels in the clouds". The artists and audiences of the time understood it as an artistic device representing the influence of the Christian God, not extraterrestrials. The device is seen more clearly in many contemporary works, notably Luca Signorelli's 1491 Annunciation.[89]

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: Several precursors to modern flying saucers appeared in science fiction literature, including The Shaver Mystery.[90] Richard Sharpe Shaver's stories about a secret technologically advanced civilization of "detrimental robots" inside the earth were published as a true account of his life.[49] Backlash from the science fiction community carried over to UFO literature.[13] Saucers did appear in conventional science fiction,[91] but a genre emerged that treated fantastical stories as either true or plausibly true.[92] The debut issue of Mystic magazine asked readers, "When you read this story, you will tell yourself that it is fiction; the editors assure you that it is. But what if—it isn't?"[93] The Fortec Conspiracy, a science fiction novel, both drew from and fed into crashed saucer rumors.[94] Major newspapers rarely did reviews for saucer books but printed their sensationalist advertisements claiming to prove that flying saucers had landed or were being covered up. Cultural studies scholar Jonathan Gray describes this type of widely-viewed alarmist ad as a paratext (related to the central text but not a part of it), which can reach a much broader audience than the text itself.[95]

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: Advertisements leveraged cultural interest in flying saucers from the earliest reports. Magazines were promoted as offering skeptical, debunking explanations for the phenomenon. From 1947 into the 1970s, marketing leveraged the discs' potential as advanced technology. By the 1980s, saucers in advertisement were used to evoke awe towards their potential pilots more than futurism.[95]

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: Aliens and flying discs were common in 1950s science fiction comics that flourished after the Golden Age of Comic Books.[97] Launched in the 1960s, the comic book anthology UFO Flying Saucers featured illustrations of supposedly real sightings.[97] The opening to its first issue declared, "Our scientists have seen them! Our airmen have fought them!"[98] As the 1950s progressed, former pulp readers turned their attention to the growing medium of television.[99]

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: Many early portrayals of flying saucers linked them to the Cold War.[5]: 65  The 1949 film serial Bruce Gentry – Daredevil of the Skies featured a man-made flying saucer,[100] and the 1950 film The Flying Saucer focused on Cold War espionage.[5]: 65  Saucer films in the 1950s featured alien pilots, but many continued to center on Cold War fears.[101]: 14, 67  The Thing from Another World (1951) was a loose adaptation of John W. Campbell's "Who Goes There?", updated to include aliens and relocated to Alaska, where Americans feared a Russian attack.[101]: 44  Later that year, The Day the Earth Stood Still had its human-looking alien Klaatu give audiences explicit warnings about a possible nuclear holocaust.[101]: 4  The Day the Earth Stood Still and The Thing from Another World were financial successes that established the market for an "alien visitor" subgenre of science fiction that merged flying saucers into existing space opera tropes.[5]: 66  Slowly hovering discs, such as the one from the landing scene in The Day the Earth Stood Still, appeared throughout science fiction, including It Came from Outer Space (1953),  Earth vs. the Flying Saucers (1956), and the television series The Invaders.[85]: 175  While contactees described aliens as benevolent messengers, Hollywood films often depicted them as monstrous antagonists.[5]: 222

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: Other countries adapted the largely American phenomenon at different times, adding elements of the local culture. Early British films were low-budget productions such as Devil Girl from Mars (1954) and Stranger from Venus (1954).[102][103] Japanese filmmakers incorporated flying discs and alien invaders into the tokusatsu tradition in mid-50s films such as Fearful Attack of the Flying Saucers and Warning from Space.[104] Indian cinema began to incorporate alien invaders in the 1960s, starting with the Tamil-language Kalai Arasi.[105] An adaptation of Bankubabur Bandhu by Satyajit Ray was never completed but may have influenced other works of science fiction.[106] In Spain, alien-themed television shows became popular in the 1960s.[5]: 174

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs:
Flying saucers quickly spread to other genres. In Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's big-budget Forbidden Planet, a futuristic 1956 adaptation of William Shakespeare's play The Tempest, humans travel through space in the United Planets Cruiser C-57D, a ship resembling a flying saucer.[107] The Twilight Zone episodes "The Monsters Are Due on Maple Street", "Third from the Sun", "Death Ship", "To Serve Man", "The Invaders", and "On Thursday We Leave for Home", all make use of the iconic saucer from Forbidden Planet.
[108] The C-57D was followed by other disc-shaped spacecraft in broader science fiction, such as the Jupiter 2 from the television series Lost in Space (1965–1968).[109] Saucers appeared in the television series Babylon 5 (1994–1998) as starships used by a race called the Vree.[110] Aliens in the film Independence Day (1996) attacked humanity in giant city-sized saucer-shaped spaceships.[111]

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: Flying saucers were supplanted by other concepts and fell out of favor with Hollywood filmmakers.[66][101]: 106  After 1956, American saucer films were mainly B movies. Plan 9 from Outer Space is infamous for its "pie-pan" saucers dangled from visible piano wire.[112][101]: 62, 93  Television shows and British films continued to depict flying discs and alien invaders into the 1960s.[101]: 106  Various saucer designs have appeared in Doctor Who, such as those used by the Daleks in Daleks' Invasion Earth 2150 A.D. or the Cybermen in "The Tenth Planet".[113][114] Italy produced a wave of low-budget films, often space operas or comedies, including Omicron (1963) and Il disco volante (1964).[101]: 107–122  By the end of the 1960s, Japan, Italy, and Britain largely ceased producing saucer films.[101]: 143  Disc-shaped spacecraft fell out of favor in straight science fiction but continued to be used ironically in comedies.[115][66] The image is often invoked retrofuturistically to produce a nostalgic feel in period works.[86] For example, Mars Attacks! (1996) draws on the flying saucer as part of the larger satire of 1950s B movie tropes.[116]

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: The sleek, silver flying saucer is widely regarded as a symbol of 1950s culture.[66] The motif is common in Googie architecture and Atomic Age décor.[117]  Notable flying saucer structures include Seattle's Space Needle and Los Angeles International Airport's Theme Building.[118][119] Googie architecture in California, such as the Chemosphere home, influenced the futuristic structures in the 1960s cartoon The Jetsons. The cartoon popularized the style to such an extent, that it is often referred to as the "Jetsons look".[120] Architect Frank Lloyd Wright, who collaborated on the design of the flying saucer in The Day The Earth Stood Still, went on to use the flying saucer as an architectural motif.[121][122] Wright's circular Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church in Wauwatosa, Wisconsin, United States, is capped by a flattened dome over a hundred feet across.[123]

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: Spaceships are one of the subjects of novelty architecture. Also known as mimetic architecture, novelty architecture is the practice of creating structures shaped like other existing objects.[124] The Communist-era Kielce Bus Station in Kielce, Poland, was designed by architect Edward Modrzejewski [pl] to resemble a UFO.[125] The historic landmark arena in Katowice, Poland, is called Spodek (Polish for "saucer") based on its resemblance to the saucers of 1960s science fiction.[126] Other modernist and brutalist UFO structures include the Ukrainian Institute of Scientific, Technical and Economic Information,[127] Bulgaria's concrete Buzludzha monument,[128] the Most SNP in Bratislava, Slovakia,[129] and The Flying Saucer in Sharjah, United Arab Emirates.[130] The Westall UFO was commemorated with the Grange Reserve UFO Park, featuring a UFO with red slides modeled after the reported sighting.[131] Roswell, New Mexico, is a UFO tourist destination in the Southwestern United States. Many structures in Roswell, including the streetlights and the McDonald's, are designed around alien themes.[132] Moonbeam, Ontario, Canada, has an alien for its mascot and a prominent roadside flying saucer at its welcome center.[133] UFO-shaped homes include the Futuro pods designed by Matti Suuronen,[134] the former Sanzhi UFO houses from the Sanzhi District, New Taipei, Taiwan,[135] and artist Harry Visser's iconic home in Roodepoort, Johannesburg, South Africa.[136]

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: Flying saucers were a ubiquitous part of pop culture from 1947 into the mid-1970s.[97] Flying disc motifs were used in toys and other novelties soon after the earliest reports. The frisbee was released in 1948 and initially branded the "flying saucer".[137] Flying saucer candy was introduced in the 1950s when a Belgian producer of communion wafers had a dip in sales.[138] Along with other vintage candies, they have since seen renewed interest from customers as "retro".[139] In the 1950s and early 1960s, Japan was a major manufacturer of tin toys often with space themes such as robots, rockets, and flying discs.[140] Throughout the 1950s, musicians such as Billy Lee Riley, Jesse Lee Turner, and Betty Johnson released novelty songs about flying discs and alien invaders. Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman released the first break-in record, "The Flying Saucer", which took the form of a mock news broadcast covering an alien invasion.[141] Disneyland opened Flying Saucers, an attraction where guests could pilot a hovering disc by tilting their own body.[75]

name: Flying_saucer
paragraphs: Video games have a long history of depicting flying saucers, typically as antagonists.[142] In the arcades, the popular early shooting games Asteroids (1979) and Space Invaders (1978) featured flying saucers as "bonus" enemies that only emerged briefly.[143] Super Mario Land, one of Nintendo's launch titles for the original Game Boy, contained spaceships modeled after photographs by George Adamski and set among various monuments falsely attributed to ancient astronauts, such as the Egyptian pyramids and the monolithic Moai of Easter Island.[144] The XCOM series tasks players with countering an invasion of aliens landing on Earth in flying discs. Saucers have appeared as a craft that players can control in Fortnite, Destroy All Humans, and Spore.[142]
